TOKENS: p e t e ĩ
NOTES: Guarani-speaking people originally counted up to four. The present Paraguayan Guarani numeral system is attributed to Reinaldo Decoud Larrosa.

TOKENS: m o k õ i
NOTES: /eĩ/ and /õi/ should be diphthongs. In the available literature (ParaguayanGuarani1, ParaguayanGuarani3, ParaguayanGuarani4), I find no evidence that diphthongs are monophonematic units. I only find some evidence that they are not in ParaguayanGuarani1[29-30], where they are considered vowel sequences, so I also consider the two separate units. When /i/ in a diphthong is realized as a glide, it is still represented as /i/ in ParaguayanGuarani1[29-30], which I follow here.

TOKENS: ᵐb o h a p ɨ
i ɾ u ⁿd ɨ
p o
p o + t e ĩ
NOTES: the morpheme teĩ is the shortened form of peteĩ

TOKENS: p o + k õ i
NOTES: the morpheme kõi is the shortened form of mokõi

TOKENS: p o + a p ɨ
NOTES: the morpheme apɨ is the shortened form of ᵐbohapɨ

TOKENS: p o + -/i ɾ u ⁿd ɨ
NOTES: the morpheme ɾuⁿdɨ is the shortened form of iɾuⁿdɨ

TOKENS: p a
NOTES: pa stems from "opa ‘end, totality, complete’, because 10 is the modern decimal system." (ParaguayanGuarani1[100])
